If you’re on social media today and agree please get the word out on this and contact your Senators. It’s not too late. The bill isn’t finished. A big, bipartisan coalition can still win this. We can #GoBig4Charity. Who’s with me? (15/15)

This is not a partisan or ideological issue. It’s more like a blind spot we want everyone to see. Congress is understandably focused on business liquidity. We’re digging deep to rescue the economy. We have to do the same for our equally important civil society. (14/15)

That’s why a one-year, charitable deduction is essential to a comprehensive coronavirus relief package. Rs and Ds are ready to #GoBig4Charity. We just need the chance to show it. The base bill can still be changed, or we try to offer a bipartisan amendment on the floor. (13/15)

This morning, millions are attending virtual church services in their living rooms, praying that this crisis passes. And it will. And when it does, we’re going to need those churches, and all our service orgs, back on the front lines to rebuild and renew our communities. (12/15)

And based on conversations I’ve had the last few days with Republican and Democrat colleagues, I am morally certain that there is overwhelming bipartisan support for a huge-but-temporary, one-year policy fix for the charitable giving deduction. (11/15)

This year, we’re going to *want* all Americans – especially rich ones! – pouring their money into local charities. If there must be a cap, $300,000 or $30,000 makes *much* more sense than $300. (10/15)

The American people are ready to “go big” with their own personal contributions to the national relief effort. But Congress has to help them do it. In all honesty, for this one year, the deduction shouldn’t be capped at all. (9/15)

Non-profits are looking at shortfalls this year in the tens, maybe hundreds of billions of dollars. Ten percent of U.S. jobs are in the non-profit sector. These organizations don’t need a bailout – they need blow-out. Just this one time, this one year. (8/15)

This is crucial. Fixing the charitable deduction for 2020 may give our relief efforts the best policy bang for the buck. Unfortunately, the draft proposal would cap this special, one-time deduction at… $300 per person! That’s short by at least one zero. (7/15)

The good news is, negotiators of Phase 3 are aware of this need. The first draft includes a 1 time, 1 year fix that moves the charitable deduction “above the line” on 2020 tax forms. That would enable all tax filers to deduct charitable donations from their taxable income. (6/15)

Ivy League universities and the Smithsonian Institution may be fine. But small and medium-sized local non-profits – the lifeblood of American culture, cooperation, and community – are going to be hanging by a thread. Congress has to make them a priority. (5/15)

Think about what months of social distancing and shrunken family budgets will do to churches, charities, soup kitchens, homeless shelters, drug rehab centers, museums, elderly outreach, libraries, youth sports leagues, orchestras and theater companies? (4/15)
It’s not just the for-profit economy that is suffering and will suffer from the COVID outbreak. Civil society – all those millions of non-profits around the country – are getting hammered too. (3/15)

In D.C., the theme of the relief effort is to “go big.” Members on both sides want to overwhelm the fears and uncertainty now strangling our economy. But in this crisis, it’s not enough just for the *government* to “go big” – we have to empower *everyone* to go big, too. (2/15)
A quick Sunday morning thread on the urgent need for Congress’s coronavirus relief package to include a massive, one-year expansion of the tax deduction for charitable giving: (1/15)
